title: BP swings highest annual profit eight years
story: Share this article The policy had been delayed by weeks of internal wrangling with Boris Johnson and the Cabinet, after many ministers pushed for the £12billion national insurance raid to be delayed or axed.Labour accused Mr Sunak of a 'puny' response and a 'buy now pay later' approach, arguing he is merely delaying the pain.He was also assailed by some Tory MPs, with Peter Bone branding him a 'socialist' in an extraordinary barb.  Mr Sunak said: 'We are delivering that support in three different ways. First we will spread the worst of the extra costs of this year's energy price shock over time. This year all domestic electricity customers will receive an up front discount on their bills worth £200.'Energy suppliers will apply the discount on people's bills from October with the Government meeting the cost in full, that discount will automatically be repaid from people's bills in equal £40 instalments over the next five years.' Alarmingly many members of the Monetary Policy Committee pushed for a bigger rates increase to 0.75 per cent. Investors are anticipating the level will reach 1.5 per cent by the end of the year.Governor Andrew Bailey said it had been a 'close call' but stressed there was only likely to be 'modest' further increases in the coming months.He said the Bank had not acted because the economy is 'roaring away', but to counter the risk that inflation is becoming 'ingrained' domestically. The new peak is two percentage points higher than was forecast in November. Experts are warning the cost-of-living crisis could last years, with ministers hitting the panic button amid fears it will be even more toxic to the government than Partygate.Mr Sunak told MPs: 'The price cap has meant that the impact of soaring gas prices has so far fallen predominantly on energy companies, so much so that some suppliers who could not afford to meet those extra costs have gone out of business as a result.'It is not sustainable to keep holding the price of energy artificially low. For me to stand here and pretend we don't have to adjust to paying higher prices would be wrong and dishonest.'But what we can do is take the sting out of a significant price shock for millions of families by making sure the increase in prices is smaller initially and spread over a longer period.'He added: 'Without Government intervention the increase in the price cap would leave the average household having to find an extra £693, the actions I'm announcing today will provide to the vast majority of households just over half of that amount, £350.' The Ofgem move is likely to impact 22million households across Great Britain, and applies to those who are on their energy supplier's default tariff.'We know this rise will be extremely worrying for many people, especially those who are struggling to make ends meet, and Ofgem will ensure energy companies support their customers in any way they can,' the watchdog's chief executive Jonathan Brearley said.'The energy market has faced a huge challenge due to the unprecedented increase in global gas prices, a once in a 30-year event, and Ofgem's role as energy regulator is to ensure that, under the price cap, energy companies can only charge a fair price based on the true cost of supplying electricity and gas.' Meanwhile, Labour has renewed its demand for a windfall tax on energy companies after Shell recorded an eye-watering £12billion profit in just three months.

BP made almost $2.7bn of pre-tax profits from its stake in the Kremlin-controlled Rosneft during 2021, today’s results show, compared with a loss of $238m in 2020. BP says this recovery is due to higher oil prices and favourable foreign exchange effects during last year. title: end mass testing now let us return normality
story: Britain has got itself into a terrible mess on mass testing. A recent study led by Oxford academics, which found that up to a third of people found positive on a PCR test were not contagious, should give the Government cause to reconsider the wisdom of this approach.At an inidual level, knowing your own infection status can be extremely helpful, for example if you are planning to visit a vulnerable relative or friend. However, as we all know, a positive test result can have significant negative impacts, particularly if it entails loss of income and opportunity. If the tests are too sensitive, the problem is even worse.Furthermore, the truth is that we are permanently crawling with germs. Expecting the inidual to bear responsibility for any infection that he or she might pass on risks leaving us all living in a state of permanent guilt. Normally, this guilt is dispersed within the community.This is not to say that, during a pandemic, we should not exercise care to protect the vulnerable by limiting contact with them while we are infectious (in fact, I would highly recommend this) but it is also important to remember that once a disease has become endemic, there is little else we can do other than not visit granny when we have a fulminant cold.But to what extent should we self-isolate upon testing positive or being told that we may have been in contact with someone who tested positive? As we have witnessed over the past few months, these actions do little to stop the spread of infection and create enormous problems for the delivery of healthcare and education. Sanctioning the use of tests that suggest people are contagious even when they are not magnifies the problem.It is, however, important to recognise that things would not have been much different if we had a perfect test, as in some sense we now have with the new generation of LFDs. We would still have vast numbers of key workers unable to function and children being deprived of the safety and intellectual and emotional stimulation that our educational system seeks to provide. We would still have to endure life being endlessly disrupted – all having scant impact on the prevalence of an infection in its endemic state.Testing could have been profitably used at the population scale. Even imperfect measurements of the incidence of infection done randomly could have allowed us to make intelligent assessments regarding the progression of the pandemic and the effects of the restrictions, allowing greater flexibility and better tailoring advice to the vulnerable and the NHS.Some deficiencies in the rigour of testing early in the pandemic, given that we were dealing with an emergency, could be tolerated on the basis that it was important to garner information on the development of the situation. What cannot be forgiven is that, instead, we used a faulty testing scheme to transfer societal responsibilities to the inidual, sentencing many to loss of livelihood, education, social contact and hope – and we still are.Continuing with a mass testing, mass isolation strategy in response to a disease that has become endemic is merely piling up the misery. The Government must change course.Sunetra Gupta is professor of theoretical epidemiology at the Department of Zoology, University of OxfordMore from NewsPolitics latest news: Boris Johnson &#39not to blame&#39 for harassment of Sir Keir Starmer, minister saysRepublicans urged to stay out of Ottawa trucker protest as court bans horn honking Ukraine latest news: Putin moving towards de-escalation, say French officialsPolice rescue Sir Keir Starmer from mob who surround him and accuse him of &#39protecting paedophiles&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: paraplegic man walks thanks electronic implant spine
story: A completely paralysed man was able to walk again at the touch of a button after an electronic implant was placed in his spine in a groundbreaking operation.Italian Michel Roccati had no movement or feeling in his legs following a motorcycle accident in 2017 which severed the nerves in his spinal cord.However, after Swiss researchers implanted an electronic array, which stimulates the nerves below the injury, he was instantly able to stand and walk, and has since been able to cycle and swim.“The first few steps were incredible – a dream come true. It was very emotional to see my legs moving,” said the 30-year-old.“I’ve been through some pretty intense training in the past few months, and I’ve set myself a series of goals. For instance, I can now go up and down stairs, and I hope to be able to walk one kilometre by this spring.”Similar technology has been used to help patients with partial paralysis, but it is the first time it has been shown to work in people who had no movement at all.The implant was developed by scientists at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (EPFL) and Lausanne University Hospital, and works by stimulating the region of the spinal cord that activates specific muscle groups in the trunk and legs.The team needs at least six centimetres (2.4 inches) of healthy spinal cord below the injury so that the implant can stimulate certain nerves. It is fitted underneath the vertebrae, inside the spinal column. They then use artificial intelligence to discover the sequence of neurons which fire in iniduals when they want to carry out various activities, such as walking, cycling and even canoeing.At the moment, the implant uses just 16 electrodes to stimulate the nerves, but in time, the researchers want to move to 32 or 64 to gain even greater control.After the implant, patients need about 10 days of recovery, before the implant can be switched on. As well as Mr Roccati, it has been also trialled successfully on three other patients.Prof Gregoire Courtine, a neuroscientist from EPFL, said: “Our stimulation algorithms are based on imitating nature, and work exactly in the way that the spinal cord is stimulated by the brain. “When you first turn it on you can stand, and step but you still need support, and the gait pattern is poor, but it allows you to start training all this activity immediately, and over the course of several months we can decrease the support.“All three patients were able to stand, walk, pedal, swim and control their torso movements in just one day, after their implants were activated. That’s thanks to the specific stimulation programs we wrote for each type of activity.“We are not yet at the stage where it’s a commercially available technology that you can use with your smartphone, but that’s our next objective.”For Mr Roccati’s first attempt, two small remote controls were attached to a walker to help him support himself because years of inactivity meant his muscles were severely wasted. The remote controls were attached wirelessly to a tablet which forwards the correct signals to a pacemaker in his abdomen. That pacemaker then relays the signals to the implant which stimulates specific neurons in a specific sequence, allowing the muscles to fire up in the correct order.Mr Roccati underwent surgery for the implant last August and has been steadily improving ever since.He said: “I had an accident on a motorbike and I immediately understood there was something wrong. I tried to move my legs and saw it was impossible. But I fixed in my mind that it was a problem to be solved.“I was living with my parents, and now I have an apartment and I can do everything alone no problem.”Dr Jocelyne Bloch, a neurosurgeon at Lausanne University Hospital, added: “There are so many patients around the world who need a treatment to fight against paralysis.“This technology is so precise that immediately after the surgery, the patient can walk and stand. The electrodes are arranged in a way that corresponds exactly to the spinal nerve roots.“That gives us precise control over the neurons regulating specific muscles. Ultimately, it allows for greater selectivity and accuracy in controlling the motor sequences for a given activity.”While the progress achievable in a single day is groundbreaking, the gains after several months are even more impressive.The three patients were able to regain muscle mass, move around more independently, and take part in social activities like having a drink standing at a bar.The team is now working with Onward Medical, a medical technology company, to move the technology to a smartphone, so patients can simply select the activity they need.Larger clinical trials will be taking place in the US and Europe imminently, with the team hoping the device will be available within the next two to three years.Details of the research were published in the journal Nature Medicine.More from NewsRepublicans urged to stay out of Ottawa trucker protest as court bans horn honking Ukraine latest news: Putin moving towards de-escalation, say French officialsPolitics latest news: Boris Johnson &#39not to blame&#39 for harassment of Sir Keir Starmer, minister saysPolice rescue Sir Keir Starmer from mob who surround him and accuse him of &#39protecting paedophiles&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: obese get weight loss jabs effective gastric band
story: Weight loss jabs that are as effective as a gastric band are to start being prescribed by the NHS. The National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (Nice) is expected to give the green light to Wegovy, a once-weekly injection that suppresses appetite.Trials have found that those put on the treatment lost an average of almost two-and-a-half stone, compared with those given a placebo.Researchers last year said the treatment was a “game-changer”, with results comparable to those of weight loss surgery. One-third of those taking part in the trial lost an average of a fifth of their total body weight. The new recommendations are expected to recommend the treatment to those with a body mass index of 30 or over if they have been referred for specialist help, and to anyone with a  BMI of 35 or more with a weight-related health problem. More than one in four people in the UK are obese, which means a BMI of 30 or over. Experts said the treatment, manufactured by Novo Nordisk, should be taken alongside changes in dietary habits and exercise habits. The drug works by hijacking the body's own appetite-regulating system in the brain, leading to reduced hunger and calorie intake. Research last year found that those put on the regime lost five times as much weight as those in the placebo group.When the results were published, Rachel Batterham, lead researcher for the project and professor of obesity, diabetes and endocrinology at University College London, said they were “a major breakthrough for improving the health of people with obesity”.“No other drug has come close to producing this level of weight loss - this really is a gamechanger,” she said. “For the first time, people can achieve through drugs what was only possible through weight-loss surgery.”Britain has some of the worst rates of obesity in the Western world, with two in three adults overweight or obese.Last week, NHS research found slimmers put on an NHS regime of soup and shakes to reverse diabetes have lost an average of two stone in just three months.More from NewsUkraine latest news: Kremlin denies promising Macron no new military exercises near Ukraine&#39s borderPolitics latest news: Boris Johnson &#39not to blame&#39 for harassment of Sir Keir Starmer, minister saysRepublicans urged to stay out of Ottawa trucker protest as court bans horn honking Police rescue Sir Keir Starmer from mob who surround him and accuse him of &#39protecting paedophiles&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: special advisors mustnt become special
story: My first thought on last week’s resignation of Munira Mirza, the head of Boris Johnson’s Policy Unit, was that this was the worst blow so far in his current crisis. Ms Mirza is a brave, principled, straight-dealing person who has an unusual combination of strong intellectual powers and the ability to get things done. Far from being a rat leaving the sinking ship, she was a key figure in the engine room. Boris desperately needs such people near him.I still think that. But I think something else as well, which is that the public cult of the adviser has gone too far. At their best, the special advisers to prime ministers and other ministers, known as “Spads”, are invaluable – the ones at the top, such as Ms Mirza, even more so. They fight for their bosses against suffocation by officialdom and help manage their relationships with the media. Without them, it is hard to develop policy and drive through the central aims of any government.But, as a trainspotting friend informs me, the initials SPAD mean, in railway parlance, “Signal Passed At Danger”. That signal was passed in Tony Blair’s era by Alastair Campbell and, in Boris’s, by Dominic Cummings.However talented, advisers shine only with a “borrowed light”. Their duty is to advise their principal and otherwise to shut up. If their principal wants them out, they must go, without public complaint. If they wish to leave, they should do so, without publishing a letter about it attacking their boss (as Ms Mirza has just done). Nor should they wage war against their former boss forever after, as Mr Cummings does – even saying last year that his intention on coming into office under Boris Johnson had been to work to get Boris Johnson out.It is not relevant here whether their criticisms are right. I think Mr Cummings had a good understanding of Boris’s shortcomings and many good ideas for policy reform. I know that Ms Mirza was always fighting valiantly to improve the coherence of policy against Boris’s temptation to fuzz things up.No, the problem is two-fold. The first is a fact that should be obvious in any organisation – no one can run anything if hisher right to lead is not respected. That includes the right to make the wrong decisions. Advisers, by definition, do not decide. If they cannot accept that basic rule, they should not be doing their jobs.The second is a democratic one. Governments are formed as a result of elections, and largely composed of people whom voters elected. If unelected advisers are trying to run the show, or plotting to depose elected people, they are showing contempt for the voters. They are undermining the legitimacy of the entire system.Mr Cummings’s great Vote Leave slogan was “Take back control”. If he had said “Give me control” instead, the public would never have voted Leave.Something very strange is therefore coming about. One of the main purposes of advisers – particularly in a Conservative government against which Whitehall is biased – is supposed to be to take on the so-called “Blob” of bureaucrats and quangos. The advisers are put in to help break the stranglehold of unelected power. But if they are simply a different unelected power, attempting to gain a stranglehold of their own, what good is that to voters?The Blob and the anti-Blob may hate one another, but they come perilously close to the same thing – a conspiracy against the public.The announcement that the Duchess of Cornwall will become Queen Consort when her husband succeeds to the throne has been well handled.To coincide with her 70 years as monarch, the Queen has expressed this as her wish. Who can challenge her?Not for the first time, the Queen has picked the right moment. It reminds me of when, in 2018, she took advantage of the Commonwealth conference in London to persuade the assembled leaders that the Prince of Wales should be made Head of the Commonwealth on her death. They wanted to grant her wish.If it had been rushed, the decision about the Queen Consort could have caused an explosion. As Editor of this paper at the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997, I remember how vehement many of our readers felt against the then Camilla Parker Bowles.Most of them were not such extreme members of the Diana camp that they wanted the Prince of Wales passed over in favour of Prince William but many were very upset at the way they felt Diana had been treated. Mrs Parker Bowles became the target of their wrath. They did not want her to benefit, as they saw it, from the breakup and the tragedy of Diana’s death.It was because of feelings such as these that, when the couple did eventually marry in 2005, she became only the Duchess of Cornwall, not the Princess of Wales. But, as so often happens with marital break-ups, the sense of taking sides sharply reduces over time. If the new partner politely plays it long, shehe is accepted.Thanks to Camilla’s good sense and good will, that has clearly happened. She will never become – to use Diana’s own phrase about herself – our “Queen of Hearts” and has never for a moment sought such a vainglorious role.All the more reason to think she will be a good Queen Consort.More from NewsRepublicans urged to stay out of Ottawa trucker protest as court bans horn honking Ukraine latest news: Putin moving towards de-escalation, say French officialsPolitics latest news: Boris Johnson &#39not to blame&#39 for harassment of Sir Keir Starmer, minister saysPolice rescue Sir Keir Starmer from mob who surround him and accuse him of &#39protecting paedophiles&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: boris rishi need good neighbours
story: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours... but the Boris and Rishi fairytale is going to end in tearsDowning Street has found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, says Fleet Street Fox. But how long will Errorsboroughs marriage of convenience last Its the wedding of Rot and Brylcreem - a match made in hellopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsIf thereaposs one thing that Boris Johnson is disciplined about, itaposs control. Specically, not being subject to it. Wedding vows, lockdown rules, basic morality, the Ministerial Code, his own manesto: the default response of the Prime Minister to all of them is PAH! Which is why itaposs interesting that, a week after the worst week in his premiership since the previous worst week, which was only the week before, the PM is now submitting himself to the control of his Chancellor of the Exchequer.In a single weekend, Rishi Sunakaposs mates have moved into No, expensive policy announcements have been binned, and the crime of fraud which has taken £bn off the taxpayer on Covid alone has been downgraded to a harmless infraction of little consequence.  Unfortunately, this whirlwind romance is headed for some very big and pointy rocks.The first is that the cost of living crisis, which is already a crisis, is going to get worse with food costs predicted by millionaires to rise another % in April. No-one knows what to call something worse than a crisis, but the dictionary will probably need updating to include something like crisaster.The second is the energy crisis, in which the taxpayer has been forced to compensate corporate giants for not being able to steal money immediately, and instead letting them steal it over  years. Prices are likely to rise again in the autumn, and because  months was too long for billion-pound firms to wait, the government may allow an extra price rise in the summer to tide them over. Presumably, weaposll be calling this frobbery.If Boris thinks Her Upstairs is dficult to live with, heaposs going to flip when he finds out that Rishi is the sort of spouse whoaposll give him £ towards the housekeeping, and then ask for £ back by exerting some below-inflation fiscal drag on state pensions. On the face of it, their relationship is rooted in shared politics and a mutual love of money. But while one partner is a hedge funder whoaposs got more money than the Queen, the other never carries cash because he canapost hold onto it for more than  minutes.Both of them seem unable to spot a party when it involves  people, soft drinks, beer, renditions of Happy Birthday, a society wallpaperer, an official photographer, a strategically-sly cake, and a police investigation. Both, according to reports, are also capable of enjoying all that in the space of just  minutes before getting on with the job, which is a polite way of saying you burped all afternoon.But thereaposs little  these two have in common. One is a spender, the other a spaffer. One drinks beer, the other power. One is vain enough to arrange photocalls on staircases so he doesnapost look as short, while the other has just one suit and no comb. Read moreToday, weaposre told that a major announcement on Borisapos big promise to use the £bn National Insurance increase to bring down NHS waiting lists has been boiled down to a website, so that you can stop ringing the doctor to find out about your appointment and just throw the computer out of the window instead.Officially, the plan isnapost ready yet, and unofficially Rishiaposs blocking it until heaposs PM and can announce it himself. And therein lies the problem with this partnership: only last week, Johnsonaposs friends were telling him to kick Sunak out, on the grounds he was trying to steal his job.Imagine a bride trying to get the groom sacked, withholding cash while giving it to rich mates, giving Princess Diana eyes in TV interviews whenever sheaposs asked about parties. Picture a groom so desperate to keep the house that heaposll overlook their dferences, let her take total control, and start measuring up for curtains he will never get to see.Think about a relationship in that much trouble before its second anniversary. It might work in an Australian daytime soap, but it ainapost going to last in a world where people donapost come back from the dead after  years lost at sea. Johnson thinks heaposs saved his skin by ceding control to his most ambitious enemy, and boasts it would now take a Panzer ision to get him out of No. Sunak, meanwhile, is quietly lining up his tanks in the Downing Street garden, which he has always had a great view of from his No office. The PM is being infantilised by enemies saying his we wields all the power, and potentially criminalised by his friends claiming that she has nothing to do with his work, but nevertheless attended a lot of work events.And the only PR expert who can be persuaded to enter the fray is someone who considers the PM sexually incontinent, throws Benny Hill salutes at world leaders, quotes Gloria Gaynor, and on his first day gives the press the headline: Heaposs not a COMPLETE clown. But the fundamental flaw with this great reset, which is probably more of a breather to allow Rishi to liquidate assets, is that it involves trying to instil discipline in a man who has spent a letime shucking it. The fact he needs to be taught the self-control of a toddler is why he lives in Errorsborough - a town twinned with Débâcle.Fans may think these two have found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, but itaposll last only as long as it takes for Johnson to take back being out-of-control, and Sunak deciding that his tanks are ready to evict. title: business ready give labour another
story: Exclusive: Labour business chief says firms are ready to give party a chance after Corbyns reignShadow Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds took the Mirror back to his roots in the North East as he spoke about Brexit, re-industrialisation - and his love for Sunderland AFCShadow Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds spoke exclusively to the Mirror Image: Richard RaynerByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Feb |commentsWhen Tony Blair led Labour back to power in , he had won the confidence not just of voters but also of business.But the party’s relationship with industry suffered during its  years out of office - from Ed Miliband railing against “predators” in  to Jeremy Corbyn ’s planned tax hikes.But the mood is changing, according to Shadow Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds. Speaking exclusively to the Mirror in Sunderland, he said: “They have seen we’ve changed. “People will either be very candid and say they felt the approach under the previous regime was that they just didn’t get business at all, or some will say they understood maybe where the motivations were coming from - they understood there’s not enough high-quality work in the UK, too much low-wage, low-skill work - but they just didn’t feel we were realistic in how we thought we could achieve that.Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter  “You’ve got to do that with a partnership with business. There’s no magic and to wave, it’s that framework you put in place. “It’s maybe not realistic to say you will put up taxes on businesses to such a high degree and then expect them to do the investment you want.”Industry chiefs could also be looking to Labour because of Boris Johnson ’s infamous “f*** business” rant, and as his Chancellor Rishi Sunak lts corporation tax from % to % - piling pressure on firms battling soaring energy prices, a national insurance hike and minimum wage rises. Business leaders were also spooked by the Prime Minister’s speech to the Confederation of British Industry last year, where he told guests about a recent day trip to Peppa Pig World.“People see Labour have changed, but so have the Tories,” said Mr Reynolds. “They like the change they have seen in us and they don’t like what they have seen in the Government.” He said business chiefs were put off by the PM’s “cavalier attitude” and “flippancy”. “This is a crucial time for business,” he said.  “There is this coming together this year with the national insurance tax rise, the energy price hike and inflation … it’s reasonable that they have a serious response from the PM - and they haven’t had that.” Admitting Labour had a responsibility to offer an alternative, he added: “People use our vision on the economy and relationship with business as a proxy of whether they see us as a viable government, on the whole.”Mr Reynolds, who was elected MP for Stalybridge and Hyde, Greater Manchester, in  and won a , majority at the  election, is working with party leader Keir Starmer, Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves, Shadow Climate Change Secretary Ed Miliband and Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Pat McFadden to develop an industrial strategy, which Labour hopes to unveil before its September conference.The blueprint will “be a basis for a conversation with businesses, unions and other stakeholders”, said Mr Reynolds, who wants to “re-industrialise” Britain.  He believes hailing from the North East gives him an insight into some of the biggest issues businesses face. “I know from growing up here - Labour politicians often go on about the past too much - but clearly the Miners’ Strike and the shipyard closures, no-one would say this was the strongest economy to grow up in,” he said. “If you want to do this job really well, whether you’re from a place like this, you have to understand the places like Sunderland and Tameside, where I have grown up and now have lived in my adult le, because you have to understand the story of the Industrial Revolution and how it shapes this country - particularly the Midlands and the North but then the challenges that come from the deindustrialisation of the s onwards.“That conversation has led to ‘leveling-up’ and Brexit and, for the first time, some of those places trying out the Conservative Party.“It couldn’t get more real as a background.  If Mr Reynolds succeeds in taking over at the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, he could face an economy battered by a cost-of-living crisis, struggling to find the “unicorn” of greater productivity and dealing with the highest interest rates since before the  financial meltdown. He hopes to hear from successful firms what they want from ministers. Donning a cap and hi-vis, he toured the Nissan factory this week, seeing production lines for the Qashaqi, Juke and Leaf models. Like other UK carmakers, Nissan produced fewer cars last year than during the first year of the pandemic . Figures last week showed that in , Britainaposs car assembly plants produced just , vehicles - % down on the , made in . UK factories are producing a third fewer cars than in . Output at Nissan in Sunderland, which was producing more than half a million a year, plummeted to just ,. But the factory, which employs , workers, is a leading example that Labour wants others to follow.  “The Nissan factory in Sunderland is one of the country’s - one of the world’s - most productive and efficient and world-class places,” Mr Reynolds said. “So why when we have got something as good as that, when we can do things as well as that, are we a place where our growth since the financial crisis for the last decade has been really poor, and is forecast to be poor again after we have the immediate bounce back from the pandemic  “Why are we a place where productivity is the worst it’s been for  years  “How can we, as a prospective Labour Government, learn from places like that and have the policies in place that will make sure we can offer genuinely better jobs, a better future and better growth and prosperity ” New role is demanding Since switching from Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary to the Shadow Business role in November, Jonathan Reynolds has spent more time away from home. Juggling his new job with being a dad to four children - Jack, , Bessie, , Arthur, eight, and Seth, six - is tricky. It’s demanding. Obviously I was delighted to be asked to be in the Shadow Cabinet when Keirwas elected leader,” he said.  “Work and Pensions is a challenging job -a quarter of the whole government budget. “But this is an even more demanding role because the issues we are talking about are central to the country’s success.” He admitted that balancing work and family le “can be challenging”, but added: “My we Claire is incredibly supportive - the whole family are. “The whole family have to be supportive of you to be a politician, certainly at the leading edge. It helps that he knows how to keep his children amused.  “The kids particularly liked my joke on Question Time thatBoris Johnson told me it was raining I would go outside and check,” he quipped. Returning to his roots gave him time to reflect. “It’s fun coming back home to Sunderland today. Being around the city centre and being here, you remember a lot about how you thought about things growing up,” he said. “Being at Nissan is obviously quite a novelty, that you’ve got somebody who went to the comprehensive school down the road coming back as the Shadow Business Secretary.” Mr Reynolds was just  when Jack, who is autistic, was born. “Having Jack at a young age, in terms of just who you are - maturity - it was a really big deal, and Jack having autism and the challenges around that are a really formative experience,” he said. “It was not easy at times but all of that contributes to who you are.” Footballaposs coming home Eyes lighting up as he enters Sunderland AFC’s boardroom, Jonathan Reynolds beams: “I’ve never been in here before, it’s just immense!” The local boy who now sits in the Shadow Cabinet is an avid Black Cats fan, attending a handful of home games each season and following the side away. The Stalybridge and Hyde MP’s last match was the - defeat at Portsmouth in October.  “We got hammered,” he admitted. Mr Reynolds hails from  miles away in Houghton-le-Spring and has supported the team since he was a boy. “My dad’s a Sunderland fan, my granddad was a Sunderland fan, my children are Sunderland fans - despite the fact Stalybridge is fairly close to Man City and a slightly better offer,” he said. His parents even bought him a £ brick in the ,-seater Stadium of Light as it was being built in the mid-s. Now, he is here to host a roundtable discussion with the North East Chamber of Commerce, just a few yards from the hallowed turf. Speaking at the ground after a pilgrimage to admire the mural to club legend Raich Carter, who played  games for the side in the s and captained them to FA Cup and League Championship triumphs, Mr Reynolds said: “People all around the country are passionate about where they come from and care about their football teams.“This really is an expression of identity here in Sunderland.”  He added: “The relationship between working people and football in this country is really strong. “Despite the fact it hasn’t been a particularly easy - I was going to say ‘decades’ - for Sunderland, to come back here is absolutely wonderful. The once mighty club lie third in League One - comfortably among the play off spots, though they have won just one of their past five matches. Brexit is settled  In the run-up to the  Brexit referendum, Nissan’s chairman Carlos Ghosn said that while EU membership was a decision for voters, the company believed a Remain result “makes the most sense for jobs, trade and costs”. Sunderland promptly voted .% to Leave - one of the highest Out majorities in the UK. After campaigning to stay and then promising a second referendum, Labour’s settled position is now to “make Brexit work”. Speaking after touring the Nissan plant, Shadow Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said: “There’s no way you can say there aren’t challenges that come from Brexit - the whole premise of Nissan’s investment in the s, which has grown in scale overtime, they were looking for a berth in the single market.  “Eighty-per-cent of the vehicles they make there are for export, so anything which is increasing bureaucracy, barriers to trade with the single market, it’s a challenge. “But the fact is it has happened. I think there are certainly things that can be done better, but they have got to be trade solutions.“This constitutional argument about structures and being in the European Union, that’s settled. “For Labour it’s about what are the practical things that can be done to reduce those barriers “Clearly that is one of the drag factors on growth at the minute.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Jonathan Reynolds MPJonathan ReynoldsLabour PartyPoliticsNissanNissan Motor Company, Ltd." data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: expat tells tories pay up
story: Expat tells Tories to pay up after pension frozen at £ a week for  yearsBrian Green, , from Billinge, Merseyside, emigrated to Australia in  meaning his UK state pension was frozen at £ a week and hes never benefited from the yearly increases others getBrian Green, , is furious as his state pension is ‘frozen’ at £ per week Image: End Frozen Pensions YouTubeByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Feb |comments An expat retiree has told the Government to pay up after his state pension was frozen at £-a-week for  years.Brian Green is among an estimated half a million Brits living abroad whose pension payments no longer increase at the normal rate.The -year-old, originally from Billinge near Wigan, Lancashire, moved to Queensland, Australia, with his we in  to be closer to the coupleaposs daughters, reports the . The majority of British nationals see their pension go up yearly as high as . percent, in line with average earnings or inflation under the triple lock. Even though this policy has been temporarily suspended, most will be expecting a rise this year. The Government says increases are only guaranteed for those living in the UK, the European Economic Area , Gibraltar, Switzerland and countries with a social security agreement with the UK . Mr Green and his we - who did not wish to be named - were born and lived in the UK all their lives before emigrating. Speaking to the End Frozen Pensions campaign, the pensioner said: Our pensions have been frozen for some  years. I receive £., and my we receives £..Are you affected by a pension freeze  Let us know at webnews@mirror This, I believe, is immoral. If we had chosen to live in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo or Turkey, or indeed  other countries with which the UK has a bilateral or reciprocal arrangement, our pensions would not have been frozen. Mr Green appeared to accept the idea the UK Government will not pay backdated pensions to impacted expats across the globe. However, he added: But they could start paying the full and entitled pensions from now. Today. Since leaving their home shores, Mr Green and his we have ed annually for two months. But Mr Green highlighted their pensions undergo a temporary change when they reach Britain. He continued: “During that stay, we received an increased entitlement to our pensions.  “So on Monday, when I set off, my pension is frozen in Australia. On Tuesday, when I arrive, my pension is thawed. “What does it matter where I am ” Mr Green is keen to highlight the issue which is thought to affect hundreds of thousands of people across the world. He concluded by urging the government to take action, and said: “I paraphrase the words from Sir Henry Newbolt’s splendid poem: Vitai Lampada. “Government - pay up! Pay up! And play the game.” A DWP spokesperson previously said: “We understand that people move abroad for many reasons and that this can impact on their finances. “There is information on GOV.UK about what the effect of going abroad will be on entitlement to the UK state pension. “The Government’s policy on the up-rating of the UK state pension for recipients living overseas is a longstanding one of more than  years and we continue to uprate state pensions overseas where there is a legal requirement to do so.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Department for Work and PensionsFrozenState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad four unrecognisable school run
story: Dad-of-four unrecognisable on school run with kids after dropping huge stMike Smith from Ebbw Vale, Wales, decided to change his lestyle and undergo a £. gastric sleeve procedure at a private clinic as well as ditch unhealthy food and takeawaysMike Smith, pictured before his weightloss, shed half his body weight after having a gastric sleeve and changing his lestyle Image: Mike Smith MEDIA WALESByMark SmithAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments A dad-of-four says people no longer recognise him on the school run with his kids after shedding -and-a-half stone.Mike Smith from Ebbw Vale, Wales, said he was so unfit that he would struggle to walk around the supermarket without getting out of breath.Mike said he has now lost so much weight that some people fail to recognise him.He told WalesOnline : The kids now say to me aposdo we have to walk to school, Dad apos Le has improved tenfold - everything is easier.The -year-old admitted his diet of takeaways and sweet treats saw his weight balloon to  stone and two pounds, leading him to suffer from terrible water retention, swelling and back pain.  But after undergoing a £, gastric sleeve procedure at a private clinic in Birmingham, coupled with a complete change in his exercise levels and eating habits, he has lost half his body weight. Speaking how his le before he lost the weight, Mike said: Movement was tough, walking was tough and exercise was tough - basically le was tough. I felt isolated by society. I just felt like people were watching me all the time. Mike decided to make a change in June  and to have gastric sleeve surgery, where a portion of the stomach is stapled off. He added: I had to go on a pre-op diet which meant I could only eat  calories a day for  days. It was brutal because at the time I was so used to eating a lot of all the wrong stuff. After the surgery, youaposre almost back to being a baby [with food]. You start on fluids, work your way up to purées and then you introduce solids after six or seven weeks to see how your body reacts. Mike, who is a healthcare worker in a psychiatric hospital, said that the surgery helped him to reduce the size of meals. He said: The gastric sleeve is a tool for weight loss, not the solution, and over time the hunger doesand itaposs easy to go back to your old habits, so you have to change your lestyle too. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.I started walking first - which began in the hospital straight after the operation - then I started walking a mile or so at home, and now Iaposm up to running K three to five times a week. He said the toughest part of his weight-loss journey is finding something to eat when he went out. He added: If I went out for a meal Iaposd be like aposwhat can I eat apos This was a problem especially early on [after the operation] as I could eat very little. Mike, whose chest size has reduced from  to  inches, said going weekly to Slimming World has also been vital in encouraging him to eat more healthily. He said: Early doors I really struggled with what to eat. You get so sick and tired of protein shakes. But in Slimming World you get loads of support, people give you ideas about what to make, and it gives me a goal to aim towards. I donapost think I would have lost the weight I haveit wasnapost for this group. It has been announced that Kate will be reading a CBeebies Bedtime Story on Sunday to mark Childrenaposs Mental Health Week, as well as the channelaposs th birthday.A sneak peek photo shows Kate sitting crossed-legged looking casual in jeans and a comfy jumper sitting by a fire as she prepares to read The Owl Who Was Afraid of the Dark by Jill Tomlinson.The book follows the story of Plop, a baby barn owl, who is helped by others to grow in confidence and overcome his fears - and the story aligns with this years’ theme of the week which is growing together. CBeebies Bedtime Stories airs every night at .pm as the final part of the channelaposs hour-long bedtime segment. But rather than have unknown presenters, stars such as Dolly Parton, Tom Hardy and Bridgertonaposs Rege-Jean Page have all rocked up to lull little ones to sleep sleep recently.Patricia Hidalgo, director of BBC Children’s and Education said: “I couldn’t be more proud to have the Duchess read a CBeebies Bedtime Story as we mark the th anniversary of our CBeebies and CBBC channels. It’s such a special and relevant tale and perfectly represents this yearaposs Children’s Mental Health week theme.I can’t wait to see her deliver her own take on such a classic story and I’m sure our audience can’t either.” Kate has been heavily involved in championing childrenaposs mental health and has taken a keen interest in early years development. Just last week, it was announced she would be carrying out a fact-finding mission to Denmark as part of her Royal Foundation Centre for Early Childhood.  Kensington Palace revealed that she will be flying solo when she travels to the capital Copenhagen for a two-day visit on February  and  without husband Prince William. It is the first time that Kate will bring the centreaposs work to the international stage and on the trip and she hopes to learn from Denmarkaposs example as a country widely recognised as a world leader in its approach and investment in early childhood development. In a personal tweet, the duchess said: “Looking forward to learning from experts, parents  practitioners about Denmark’s approach to early childhood later this month. “Denmark is a beacon of best practice in its approach to the early years, with a culture which prioritises the best start in le.” She ended the message with the Danish words “Pa snarligt gensyn”, which translate as “See you soon”, and the letter “C” to denote a personal tweet. title: hundreds dismembered skeletons found during
story: Hundreds of dismembered skeletons found during HS building workA team of around  archaeologists made the startling discovery of beheaded Roman skeletons during an excavation being carried out at Fleet Marston, near Aylesbury, in BuckinghamshireAround  beheaded skeletons were among  bodies exhumed by HS archaeologists Image: PAByJacob Paul:,  Feb |commentsArchaeologists excavating along the high-speed HS rail route have made a chilling discovery of  beheaded Roman skeletons. The dismembered bodies were found with their skulls between their legs and were among  bodies.The team of around  archaeologists made the discovery during an excavation being carried out at Fleet Marston, near Aylesbury, in Buckinghamshire,The Express reported.One possible explanation for the unusual find is that the decapitated skeletons may have belonged to criminals or outcasts. However, the bones will need to undergo proper analysis before a full conclusion can be reached. This will be completed by the researchers who will be hoping to discover new insights about Roman civilization.It is understood that although decapitation may be a horric act in modern times, the Romans saw it as a normal, albeit marginal, burial rite in the late Roman period. More than , coins and several lead weights were also found on-site, which could suggest that the excavated area was once a thriving location for trade and commerce. And a hoard of domestic objects including spoons, pins and brooches were also uncovered.  Gaming dice and bells were also found which could mean that the Romans gambled here and took part in religious activities. Helen Wass, head of heritage at HS Ltd said: “The HS archaeology programme has enabled us to learn more about our rich history in Britain. “The large Roman cemetery at Fleet Marston will enable us to gain a detailed insight into the residents of Fleet Marston and the wider Roman Britain landscape.All human remains uncovered will be treated with dignity, care, and respect and our discoveries will be shared with the community.” Richard Brown, Senior Project Manager for COPA, said: “The excavation is signicant in both enabling a clear characterization of this Roman town but also a study of many of its inhabitants.” This excavation took more than a year and was done by a team from Cotswold Archaeology and Oxford Archaeology .They were working on behalf of an HS contractor. And this is not the only shocking find that archaeologists have made along the HS line. In fact, Fleet Marston is just one out of over  archaeological sites that have been excavated since . title: i could internally decapitated any
story: I could be internally decapitated at any time due to terrying conditionA mum has been left terried after being diagnosed with a rare genetic condition that means she could be internally decapitated at any time, and is fundraising for surgeryLouise is now using GoFundMe to raise funds for surgery Image: PA Real LeByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum has told how she could be internally decapitated at any moment as a result of her terrying medical condition.Louise Turner, , says she misses dancing with her children as she desperately fights to get brain surgery that could transform her le.The former carer found out last year that her neck muscles were too weak to support her head, due to a number of conditions, leaving her in a wheelchair and unable to leave her house without a neck brace. The mum longs to walk down the aisle at her wedding but was forced to put plans for her big day on hold. Now she is seeking to raise £k for brain surgery so she can be given back her le, after a horrying few years. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereThe mum lives in Ashford, Kent with her science teacher fiancé Robin McNicoll, , and her four children Luis, , Sidney, , Travis, , and Astraea, nine,Fearing she could die at any minute, Louise feels her only hope is surgery available in Spain and is now desperately trying to fund it, saying: I try not to think about what could happen because itaposs terrying. When we first got engaged in April , it was the happiest day of my le. We were at an oak tree with a swing, Robin asked to take a photo of me and he asked me how much I loved him. I didn’t know how to respond and he askedit was enough to marry him. I was euphoric. It was the best feeling.  It was so romantic. Back then we could have never imagined anything like this happening. I want to be able to enjoy my wedding. I don’t want to be screaming and shouting in pain on what should be the best day of my le. I used to always dance with my children, but I havenapost been able to in two years and I desperately want to dance with them again on my wedding day, too. But we are having to come to terms with the fact we might not have that special day for a very long time, as all our money is going towards surgery.Louiseaposs problems started after a minor car accident in December  triggered more than two years of constant and agonising headaches and relentless pain all over her body. She said: Over the next few weeks, I started to have headaches and neck pains, but I assumed it was whiplash. Sadly, that was the start of a living nightmare for Louise, who had been diagnosed with fibromyalgia, a long-term condition causing pain all over the body, in February , after struggling to cope with stfness and pain. Before that growing up, she had always dislocated knees easily and suffered from random aches and pains, but had not thought much of it. She added: I dislocated my knee a few times, but I just assumed that was normal. I was told I was double-jointed. I had random pains that were unexplained when I was younger and Iaposve always had migraines, but I didnapost worry about them. Despite sometimes feeling like she was walking through cement because of muscle stfness, she put a brave face on things and even enjoyed a trip to Paris later that summer. But the car crash changed everything for Louise. And, in January , she started to experience tremors and what she describes as stroke-like symptoms, such as slurred speech. Since then, she has seen numerous specialists, who have given her a iety of dferent diagnoses.At one point, it was suspected she had multiple sclerosis- a condition that can affect the brain and spinal cord. At others, medics have thought she had everything from severe headaches and migraines to possible Chiari malformation, where the lower part of the brain pushes down into the spinal canal. In the meantime, Louise says her symptoms have run riot, as she has experienced everything from slurred speech to agonising headaches and a suspected stroke, which led to numerous investigations, including MRI scans. Feeling increasingly isolated and depressed, for months she was in and out of AE with a host of related problems until desperate for help, in January  she saw an otologist - a specialist in ear diseases - who suggested she joined Facebook groups for people with similar symptoms for support.This was her eureka moment as, through members of a Facebook support group, she was told about a leading expert in her type of symptoms, at the Neuroinstitut in Barcelona, Spain. After examining her MRI and other scans and speaking to her, in April  he diagnosed craniocervical instability - meaning there is excessive movement between her skull and across most of the cervical vertebrae.He recommended spinal fusion surgery, which uses donor bone to strengthen the spine, and skull base decompression surgery - an operation that involves removing a small section of bone from the base of the skull. She also had a private consultation in this country, where she was diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome- a genetic form of hypermobility. Deciding to stick with these diagnoses, Louiseaposs obstacle now is finding the funding to go to Spain, so she can be treated by the surgeon she has so much faith in. Sadly, with two private operations, airfares and accommodation to pay for while she recovers, she needs £k for surgery and another £k for the additional costs. So, she has launched a GoFundMe page, appealing to kind strangers to help her fund the medical care that she is positive will save her le and eventually see her enjoying the first dance at her wedding. She said: Having the surgery would mean we’d get our lives back, so I can be there for my children and my fiancé. With everything we’ve gone through, it’s taken a massive toll on me, but also on my family, who have become my carers. We just want to go back to a normal le. It would be priceless. It would give us a second chance at le. We could have our dream wedding, which has been put on hold. I want to be a good mum again. I want to be there for my children. I used to dance with my kids every single day and I miss those precious moments so much.You can donate to Louiseaposs fundraiser here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Multiple sclerosisWedding dayCar crashesNHS" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: levi bellfields russell confession examined
story: Exclusive: Did Levi Bellfield kill Lin and Megan Russell  Monsters confession analysed by top copFormer Met Police murder detective Peter Kirkham examines Levi Bellfield’s claims he murdered Lin and Megan Russell. Michael Stone is currently serving three le sentences for the killingsLevi Bellfield claims he bludgeoned Lin and Megan Russell to death Image: ShutterstockByTom PettorCrime EditorPeter Kirkham:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  Former Met murder detective Peter Kirkham has examined monster Levi Bellfield ’s claim that he bludgeoned Lin and Megan Russell to death.Michael Stone is currently serving three le sentences for killing mum Lin and her six-year-old daughter, who were found in a lane to death in Chillenden, Kent, in .Stone, , was also found guilty of trying to murder Megan’s sister Josie, then nine - but claims he is innocent. His solicitor says he has a statement by Bellfield, , describing how he carried out the double murder. He says he was wearing washing up gloves and holding a hammer as he stopped the family on a lane. He claims his intention was to “just attack Lin”, but changed his mind on hearing screams. He claims he threw the hammer in the river near Walton-on-Thames, Surrey. But is Bellfield – serving two whole le orders for the murders of Millie Dowler, Marsha McDonnell and Amelie Delagrange – telling the truth or playing a sick game  Here, ex-Det Chief Insp Kirkham provides his analysis – and verdict. The new statement  This will be the starting point for any potential review and will drive any further action considered necessary. Detectives would look at exactly what the statement contains and compare it with what is already in the public domain. As it runs for four pages, it sounds like it will contain a lot of detail. Bellfield will also know that the police will be expecting detailit is to be believed. The murders of Lin and Megan Russell, and the almost fatal attack on Josie, has received a huge amount of publicity over the last  years. The police would look for anything signicant in the statement which is not already in the public domain. I suspect there are very few facts left in this category, given the number of legal processes through which the case has passed and the amount of media interest and coverage. If there are any signicant dferences between Bellfield’s account and what is objectively known already then the statement will be seriously undermined. Credibility of Bellfield  Whether or not there is any new information in the statement, the credibility of Bellfield will be an important factor. If, as I suspect, there is little or new veriable information in the statement, this aspect will be of central importance. The police would ask “Is Bellfield a reliable source ”. In this case, we know he has a track record of making unreliable claims. In  he denied having anything to do with the Russell murders. He appears to like playing mind games with the police – the senior investigating officer who convicted him of the murders for which he is serving a whole le sentence, DCI Colin Sutton, below, has said as much in the past. This may well just be Bellfield’s latest attempt to confuse, embarrass or undermine the police. They will be extremely cynical and will take a considerable amount of convincing that his claim is true and reliable. Does it fit with Bellfieldaposs pattern of offending   Offenders tend to start off with more minor offences and work up to more serious ones. This also applies to the modus operandi in that they would tend to start with simpler and less dramatic methods and, over time, build to more complex methods. Unusually Bellfield is known to have committed a number of very violent murders and other attacks in the first few years of this century. Each of the offences involved Bellfield attacking a lone female in an urban environment so the circumstances of the Russell murders are very dferent. His potential involvement in these murders has been known for some time and the police have already looked at it and found no evidence linking him to them. Strength of the case against Michael Stone  The flip side of assessment of Bellfield’s admissions is looking at the strength of the case against any other suspects, in this case, Michael Stone. The case against him is not the strongest. It originally involved a number of prisoners saying he had made admissions and at least two of them have now been shown to have been mistaken or lying. The Appeal authorities are aware of this, however, and his conviction stands despite that being the case. There is very little actual, direct evidence against him but, that said, the absence of direct evidence is not evidence that he was not responsible. The circumstances of the Russell murders is such that an experienced investigator would not expect to find much,any, direct evidence. It did not take place in an area where CCTV footage might be expected. Bellfield is seeking to persuade us he is responsible for the murders for which Stone has been convicted. This means he will have to produce a very convincing admission to convince the police, the Courts or anyone  that it is true and Stone is therefore innocent. Credibility and reliability of witnesses  As well as the credibility of Bellfield himself, the police will have to look carefully at the credibility of the others involved in the case. Of central relevance in this regard is Bellfield’s ex-we who is definitely not someone who might be expected to be supportive of him. She has said that she was with Bellfield in the west London area on the day of the Russell murders, more than  miles away in Kent. She has a good reason to remember the exact day as it was her birthday and this helps to underpin her recollection. She is adamant that Bellfield had no opportunity to murder the Russells that day. Her account is about as credible and reliable as these things get. Stone’s lawyers have claimed that there is a witness who says they saw Bellfield in the area of the attack on the Russells. This witness has come forward long after the events and her “recognition” of Bellfield is based on pictures of him she has seen in the papers and on TV. Eyewitness identication is well known to be problematic as evidence. My View  As we do not know exactly what is in the statement produced by Bellfield, it is impossible to make a hard and fast decision as to whether it is likely to be reliable and true. It is, however, possible for me to give an informed professional opinion as to the likelihood of that turning out to be the case. And, in short, I have little doubt that it will turn out to be . Most,not all, of the actual checkable facts in the statement will undoubtedly turn out to be already in the public domain thanks to the acres of coverage that the murder of the Russells has received over the twenty-odd years since it happened. Bellfield has plenty of time on his hands to research the case in great detail and find even the more obscure facts, which have received little focus. He is also capable of constructing a convincing  narrative from the facts he has available and, as a murderer himself, he is well placed to come up with convincing things to fill any gaps.  He is known to lie to the police and run them around the houses. I very much suspect he doesn’t like the police at all and he might therefore be motivated to produce a  account simply to get at them. He is also known to play sick games with investigators which, intentionally or otherwise, have the effect of torturing the families of victims. It would be extremely unusual for the same offender to have committed the Russell murders as a first fatal attack, several years before falling back to a far simpler MO which he then used consistently.It would also be very unusual for him to have committed the murders so far away from the area of West London in whichhe feels confident and safe only tothere for his subsequent offending.The conviction of Stone is not based on the strongest of evidence but it has been subject to long and thorough review. Two juries were satisfied of his guilt having heard the evidence.Because of the nature of the evidence against Stone, I am not giving too much weight to the fact Stone has been convicted whenit comes to assessing the admissions by Bellfield.And, of course, evenStone were innocent, it would not mean that Bellfield is telling the truth. I do not believe that Bellfield’s admissions are convincing, on the basis of what we know right now. He has a track record of saying things and then retracting them and he is known to like playing mind games with the police. There are several “red flags” waving over his admissions. Taken together they make me believe the statement is just the latest in a long line of lies from him. Although I am pretty certain that Bellfield is very likely to have committed other serious offences for which he has not been prosecuted or convicted, I do not think that the  murders of Lin and Megan Russell are amongst them. title: man runs up 192000 phone
story: Man runs up £, phone bill in just four days during family holiday in TurkeyJohn Nisill, from Skelmersdale in Lancs, said he almost fainted when BT told him hed used GB of data - costing an eye-watering £, - while on his family break to Marmaris in Turkey in OctoberCar salesman John Nisill, , from Skelmersdale in Lancashire, says he spent just  minutes on phone calls and sent a few emails while on holiday in Turkey Image: CHRIS NEILL MAVERICK PHOTOGRAPHYByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A man nearly fainted when he was told heaposd run up nearly £k in phone charges while on a four-day family holiday in Turkey.John Nisill, , from Skelmersdale in Lancashire, claims he pinged a few emails and spent just  minutes on the phone making calls during his trip to Marmaris in October. But the car salesman was left stunned when his boss called to tell him to switch off his phone because the bill seems a little high. John said he nearly fainted when BT told him how much the GB of data heaposd used would cost. He told The Sun : “My boss called and said you’re going to have to switch off the phone. The bill seems a little high.“I said ‘What is it ’ He said £,. Next day he phoned back and said, ‘Definitely switch it off, it’s now £,’.” Johnaposs boss Paul Trotter, , of AAA Performance in Rainford Merseyside, said he nearly fell off my chair when BT shared the bill. He added: It’s obviously a computer error. I’ve had a look at the bill and it shoots up £ every  seconds or so. That’s just not possible.“EvenJohn was downloading Hollywood blockbusters there’s no way he’d have gone that much over.” Because John is on a business contract, which includes just MB of data, no warning was given when he exceeded the limit. Paul added: “I was worried at first but I’m confident BT will realise it’s just an error. “John had a great holiday so there’s no harm done and we’ve even managed to laugh about it.” A spokesman for BT said they will erase the huge bill after Johnaposs story was made public.He said: “We understand this is a very signicant bill to receive, so, on this occasion, we are waiving the surplus roaming charges. “In this case, the customer was on a BT Business mobile plan which included a monthly data allowance of MB. When travelling in Turkey he far exceeded his agreed limit by consuming GB of data. We alerted him several times that he had exceeded his data allowances, that standard roaming charges were in place and that he was incurring high usage. Our records show that the customer chose not to include a data cap as part of his plan. “We always recommend customers opt for a roaming cap, as the vast majority of our business customers do. title: once partygate brings down boris
story: Once Partygate brings down Boris itll be our turn to throw a partyIts shocking that the investigation into lockdown-busting celebrations in Downing Street is costing us a fortune, but at least we should see the back of BorisWe cant wait to wave goodbye to PM Boris Johnson Image: Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Feb |commentsEviction from Downing Street will cost Boris Johnson his longed-for legacy. It will cost us, the taxpayer, £,. That’s the price of the civil service and police time spent probing No parties that should never have happened. The nation is rightly furious that the Prime Minister cared so little for the Covid rules he himself imposed that he put living it up before his duty to protect lives and livelihoods. Our PM gave not one jot about those who were forbidden from saying a final face-to-face goodbye to a dying loved one – or the family get-togethers we all did without because we were obeying his rules. Patsy Stevenson is angry too. She was fined £ for breaking lockdown restrictions to honour the memory of murdered Sarah Everard.  There was no cheese and wine at the vigil Patsy attended on London’s Clapham Common. Yet police pinned her down to arrest her, while ignoring food and booze pouring into No. The cost of the Partygate inquiry would be better spent on shielding women and girls from the kind of predator who snatched Sarah’s le away. And this investigation would not be needed had Mr Johnson and his staff accepted that rules also apply to them. This PM is on borrowed time. We will party – legally – when it finally runs out. A great honour for Camilla Camilla Parker Bowles may have been a skilled horsewoman, but she had a rough ride of it when she became Duchess of Cornwall. Many people could not forgive her for the part she played in the break-up of Prince Charles and Princess Diana’s marriage. But that was nothing compared to the fences the Queen had to jump within her own family while trying to maintain the dignity of royalty and respect for the monarchy. Both were tarnished when grandson Prince Harry turned his back on royal duties and skipped off to America to give a toe-curling interview to Oprah Winfrey, and strike ­embarrassing deals with Netflix.  It pained the Queen greatly when she had to strip her favourite son, Prince Andrew, of his titles as he faces accusations of sexual assault in a US court. But her duty to the nation demanded it, and the Queen has always put that before personal feelings. Throughout, Camilla has been steadfastly by the Queen’s side, her support in times of trouble. And just like the Sovereign, she negotiates the pathways of public le without putting a foot wrong – a ready smile and a kind word are always on her lips. The Queen is not one to ignore such loyalty and dedication. And today, as she becomes the first British monarch to reign for  years, she wants the world to know that when the time comes, Camilla will be called Queen Consort. We are delighted Camilla is to receive the honour. As they say in royal circles, she’s a jolly good fellow. And so say all of us. Sources have confirmed to The Mirror that the Prince of Wales spoke to both of his sons in the weeks leading up to the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee anniversary, prior to the monarch’s bombshell announcement on Saturday. In the surprising announcement, Queen Elizabeth II declared it was her “sincere wish” that Camilla take on the title of Queen Consort.The move was hailed as an “extraordinary” gesture by royal watchers.She broke the news in an address to mark the anniversary of her taking the throne  years ago on February . But conventional wisdom was brushed aside in the bombshell pm statement from the Palace, announcing the monarch’s wish that Camilla be known as Queen Consort.  The conversation between the Duke of Sussex and his father come after concerns of a rt between the pair, following Harry’s departure from le as a senior working royal.A royal expert last year suggested Prince Charles was hit hard by Prince Harryaposs decision to quit the Royal Family and move to the US. title: prince charles live buckingham palace
story: Prince Charles to live at Buckingham Palace when he is king as it is monarchy HQPrince Charles is determined to be based at Buckingham Palace when he is king rather than have it only as a working base as he feels it is important that the monarch lives therePrince Charles, pictured with we Camilla, believes it is important for the monarch to be resident at Buckingham Palace, said a source Image: Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsPrince Charles plans to live at Buckingham Palace when he becomes king as he feels it is important to be based at “monarchy HQ”, it has been reported.Buckingham Palace first became the official residence of the monarch by Queen Victoria in  and there has been debate over whether it should become only a working base rather than a home. But the Prince of Wales has no doubts that he will be based at the central London palace with the Cambridges possibly living at Windsor Castle, it has been reported.Charles currently lives with his we Camilla at Clarence House, the former residence of the Queen Mother.A source said that Charles is convinced that Buckingham Palace is symbolically the home of the monarch and that he should be based there when king. They told the Daily Mail : “There is no question about it. HRH’s view is that you need a monarch at monarchy HQ. This has never been in doubt.”As well a residence for the monarch, Buckingham Palace is a working operation with more than  million tourists visiting each year and it receives almost , guests. The source continued: The Prince of Wales will not move into Buckingham Palace before he is king. But when he is, he absolutely will. Just like the Queen, it will effectively be in the aposflat above the shopapos. He feels it is right, just as the Queen does, to work out of Buckingham Palace. The Palace will still be a working and entertaining hub and will also still be open to visitors. It is a hugely important tourist attraction. But the prince can still live there at the same time, much like he does at Highgrove, which is also open to the public.  A major refurbishment has been taking place at a cost of £ million for the taxpayer where electrics and plumbing have been improved as part of a general overhaul. The royals have moved out of the building while the work is underway and is due to be completed in . The Cambridgesapos London base is currently Kensington Palace while they also have Anmer Hall on the Sandringham estate in Norfolk, given to them by the Queen. The Mirror has contacted Buckingham Palace for comment. title: queen decided five years ago
story: Queen decided five years ago to make Camilla the next queen when Charles becomes kingIn a public address to mark passing the momentous milestone of  years on the throne yesterday, the Queen said she wants the Duchess of Cornwall to be known as "Queen Consort" when Prince Charles takes the throneThe Queen reportedly gave her blessing five years ago for Prince Charles to refer to his we as Queen Camilla at his coronationByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsThe Queen reportedly decided to make Camilla the next queen five years ago. In a statement marking her th year on the throne yesterday, the monarch revealed she wants Camilla to take on the title of Queen Consort when Charles becomes King. The move was dubbed extraordinary by some experts, who thought she would follow the trend with the title of Princess Consort.But this is not the first time Her Majesty gave her permission for the duchess to take the role, according to one senior royal source.The source claims the Queen gave her blessing five years ago for Charles to call his we Queen Camila at his coronation.  After the Queenaposs announcement over the weekend, it was also reported that Camilla will receive the Queen Motheraposs priceless  crown when she ascends to the position. The crown famously features the -carat Koh-i-Noor diamond, which originated in India, in a platinum mount. The blessings piled on Camila this week are a world away from the complex relationship between her and the Queen in earlier years. Once referring to her as that wicked woman, Her Majesty disliked Camilla for what she saw as meddling in Prince Charlesaposs marriage with the late Princess Diana. But in recent years, the Queenaposs contempt cooled and insiders say she has been actively preparing the Duchess for her new role.Speaking of Charlesaposs plan to call his we Queen Camilla, the source explained: ‘This is something that has been on the Prince of Wales’ mind for some time, but the timing had to be right.There was a nervousness, they wanted to get it right. ‘It’s been a done deal for some time, but the question has been how best to execute it. You are not going to please everyone.apos  Another senior royal source reportedly said the Queen felt Camilla ‘deserved’ to get the proper title that ‘comes with the job’. They said the Duchess has never tried to aposovershadowapos and always played a apossupportive roleapos but she has also aposcarved a role out for herselfapos. Other changes to the coronation plans have also been made, with officials reportedly shortening it from usual three-hour long event to ‘better reflect the times’ and it will be more reflective of religious, cultural and ethnic ersities.  After the Queenaposs historic announcement this weekend, Charles issued his own statement stating his sheer gratitude to his mother for her support, adding: aposWe are deeply conscious of the honour represented by my mother’s wish.apos He also paid tribute to the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee this year, by saying her ‘devotion to the welfare of all her people inspires still greater admiration with each passing year’.
