story: Terrying sign your home has been marked for burglary – and how to stop it fastA home security expert has warned of the latest trick burglars are using to check which properties to rob by using kidney beans to seeresidents are at homeBurglars are trying to check which residents are away on holiday Image: Getty ImagesByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsBrits are being urged to watch out for one of the latest tactics burglars are using to mark which properties to rob. Burglars are checking whether residents are on holiday by pouring kidney beans over doorsteps at night, a home security expert has revealed. Elizabeth Johns explained that robbers use the ploy to seethe beans are cleaned up by residents in the morning - which indicatestheir hunch is right or wrong. If the kidney beans remain untouched, burglars can see the house as a potential target to break into. People are now being warned to look out for the bizarre mark left on neighbouring doorsteps and clean them up where possible.It seems ridiculous, but we heard a while back that people are putting kidney beans on the front of peopleaposs doors, Ms Johns told The Sun. Obviously,youaposre in youaposd clean them up, butyouaposre away thenthe tin of kidney beans was still there then that suggests that youaposre away. Ms Johns said the tactic was being used in the Manchester area to establishanybody is in the house because that makes it a much more desirable target. She also suggested that homeowners could ask a nearby family member or trusted neighbour to keep an eye on their house when they are away. Other methods previously reported to be used by burglars include leaving a strip of sellotape over the front door keyhole. Thieves or squatters can come to the likely conclusion that its occupants are awaythe tape is still there one or several days later. Stickers on wheelie bins and stones stacked up near doorways are other signs that could suggest burglars are targeting your home. In addition to these secret signs, residents should ensure side and back gates are secure and sheds, garages and outbuildings are locked, according to advice from Crimestoppers. It also warns not to leave garden tools or ladders outside, to fit tamper-proof automatic outside security lights and try not to leave accessible windows open at night, even when at home. story: UK homes left in darkness after gigantic cargo ship stacked with containers docksThe MOL Treasure shipping container, which measures  metres in , has arrived at the DP World Container Terminal at the Port of Southampton, bringing goods from China into the UKThe MOL Treasure shipping container is docked in the Port of Southampton Image: PAByAleks Phillips:,  Feb A huge cargo ship stacked sky high with shipping containers from China has left a number of homes on the south coast in darkness. The MOL Treasure shipping container, which measures  metres in , has arrived at the DP World Container Terminal at the Port of Southampton, bringing goods from China into the UK.The vessel docked off the coast of England after leaving Yantian on January  this year, the Express reports.According to the latest data, at the container ship port in Southampton, there are currently , container imports being handled. At the same time, there are , containers being exported.  Shipping delays at the end of last year saw concerns that food and toys could run out over Christmas, and experts have warned delays will continue through this year. Giant containers like this one are resupplying a supply chain in the Uk that has been left depleted. The lorry driver shortage has contributed to disruption at UK ports. In December Tim Morris, chief executive officer of the UK Major Ports Group, said that trade ports had become “the jam in the sandwich between surging, volatile shipping and UK supply chains badly impacted by factors such as HGV driver shortages”.  He said: “Ports have taken signicant action to respond to the challenges and build resilience. “They have extended gate opening to  , increased capacity for trucks at peak hours, sought to maximise rail freight usage within the signicant constraints of the network, created additional storage space and recruited more people. “But the pressures are being exacerbated by well-publicised issues impacting all UK supply chains, notably shortages of HGV drivers. “Ports therefore have to manage access to storage space very dynamically in extreme situations. This can mean some very limited short-term restrictions. “Ports are committed to working closely with customers and entire supply chains to keep goods moving.”Retailers have highlighted particular issues in China and east Asia, where pandemic restrictions and poor weather conditions have affected shipping.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON YantianCity of Southampton Council" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: wearing tights face effective means
story: Wearing tights on face is an effective means to stop Covid spread new study findsResearchers looked at seven dferent methods that could increase the effectiveness of masks including the use of ladies tights, rubber bands and tapeThe unusual hack could be seven times more effective than wearing a loose face mask Image: Getty Images Image SourceByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments Wearing ladiesapos tights on your face could reduce the risk of catching Covid-, according to a new study. Cambridge University researchers tested seven dferent ways to improve the effectiveness of face masks when it comes to protecting against the virus.The DIY methods included taping the mask to your face to secure it properly, which was effective but uncomfortable or using rubber bands. Other hacks included filling the gaps with bandages or tying the strings for a tighter fit. But the method which showed the most promising results was to wear tights across the bottom half of your face and over your face mask. Face coverings have been criticised for not fitting tightly enough in order to signicantly reduce the viral particles that a person breathes in or out.  But the researchers said this bizarre new hack could close the gaps around the nose and mouth and lower the amount by up to seven times more than a loose face mask. They also noted, however, that it was unlikely to be tolerated for extended periods of time given the physical and social implications of wearing pantyhose on your face in public.The study looked at data from four volunteers who tried the seven dferent methods using both surgical and KN masks, reports MailOnline.While wearing the masks, each of the volunteers did seven minutes of exercises designed to mimic real-le activities such as talking, smiling, bending over, turning their head to the side, nodding and breathing.  The scientists gave them a fit factor score based on how well the masks fit according to the filtration efficiency. They found that better fitting masks have fewer gaps between the edge and the personaposs face, meaning that the air is filtered through the mask. The most effective way of improving the fit of KN masks was using tights and cloth tape which boosted the fit factor by . and . respectively, the findings show. Using gauze to fill the gaps between the face and the KN masks only offered a slight improvement of . while using it on top of the masks only boosted the fit by .. Surgical masks worked betterworn with tights, with a score of ., orthe gaps were sealed with cloth tape, scoring ..  The least effective way of improving their fit was by using rubber bands and tying ear bands with a score of .. But the attempt was still better than wearing a mask alone. Despite the positive benefits and the accessibility of the hacks, the team noted that they were uncomfortable overall. Tights gave the volunteers high levels of discomfort and caused problems with speaking while rubber bands put pressure on the ears and face, they found. Fabric tape was comfortable to wear but not to remove and it could be dislodged over time due to sweat or moving. The researchers said that the results could help designers improve masks and fitting devices.Most scientists agree that wearing a face mask makes a limited contribution to curbing the spread of coronavirus among the wider population.Medical grade masks can be far more resistant than common surgical or cloth masks but they can also be uncomfortable and hard to get hold of. The findings were published in the journal PLOS One. title: worlds first flying bike now
story: James Bond-style flying bike goes on sale - and you dont need pilot’s licenceThe Jetson One is fully electric, does not require a pilot’s licence and can reach speeds of mph, with the makes saying riders will feel like James BondThe Jetson flying bike Image: Jetson   SWNSByAmy Reast:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments The world’s first commercially available flying bike is taking off, and could be yours for £,.The Jetson One is fully electric, does not require a pilot’s licence and can reach speeds of mph. It was launched last October and has proved so popular orders are already being taken for next year.Makers Jetson, a Swedish-Polish firm, said riders will feel like James Bond when they take to the skies.It adds this is just the beginning – with flying cars this decade. Peter Ternstrom, one half of the brains behind the Jetson One, said: “The first time I flew it, it felt amazing, it’s vibration free so nothing like a helicopter or aeroplane.  “But we have a vision way beyond the Jetson One. By the end of the decade, we want a four-seater flying car on the market, one that can replace a normal family car. “We want to make cities a better place to live and mass transport is going to need to change.” Peter and co-founder Tomasz Patan set up Jetson in  and soon created a prototype.  They developed sensors, backup motors and speed restrictors to make it safe to fly. The Jetson One does not need a runway and has been built to ensure a perfect landing. Peter said he gets a request to buy one every  minutes.  He added: “Imagine turning up to McDonald’s in one of these. People will be thinking is that James Bond  Are they even from Earth ” The Jetson One weighs kg and can fly for  minutes, with a battery charging time of around two hours. It is controlled with a joystick but cannot be flown in cities yet and is only for open land. Peter said this will change and hopes to see % of all wheeled transport moved to the air by . He adds our cities will become greener with less need for parking spaces and roads. Peter’s next plan is to create a two-seater flying car by . He said: “People think it’s crazy, but believe me, evolution happens quickly. story: Exclusive: Ukraine crisis: UK and UK working on plans for dramatic parachute drop to deter RussiaIt comes amid fears Russia is preparing to invade Ukraine, with , on the country’s eastern flank and , Moscow and Belarus soldiers to the northSoldiers from the nd Airborne Division secure equipment aboard a C- transport plane for deployment to Eastern Europe amid escalating tensions between Ukraine and Russia Image: REUTERSByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsHundreds of British and US Paratroopers are being prepared to jump into eastern Europe in the biggest joint air assault exercise of its kind in decades.It comes as Defence Secretary Ben Wallace confirmed  more troops will deploy to Poland to bolster security against Russian aggression in the region.The Mirror can reveal defence chiefs are thrashing out plans for a dramatic UK-US parachute jump into Poland as a massive show of force against Moscow.There are growing fears Russia is preparing to invade Ukraine, with , of Moscow’s forces on the country’s eastern flank and , Moscow and Belarus soldiers to the north.UK military chiefs at Permanent Joint HQ in Middlesex have been going over plans to project British military strength as a gesture of solidarity with Ukrainian forces. One plan under discussion is to parachute members of  Para and nd Airborne into Poland as a dramatic signal of defiance towards Russian President Vladimir Putin.  On Monday Mr Wallace yesterday announced another  soldiers will be sent to Poland. Speaking in London alongside his Polish counterpart Mariusz Blaszczak, the Army officer said “In that spirit of solidarity and helping share each other’s challenges of resiliences we will add to those  Royal Engineers by sending a further  British troops to Poland in a bilateral deployment to show that we can work together and send a strong signal that Britain and Poland stand side by side.” Two senior defence sources have told the Mirror the troops are “highly likely” to be paratroopers and that many of them will jump into Poland from C- troops carrier warplanes. One insider said: “This has not been absolutely finalised but these troops will very likely be from  Air Assault Brigade and they will very likely jump in.” Sources say it is many years since American and British troops parachuted together into eastern Europe, although they have done it more recently in the States. More than  members of  Para’s B Company are already in Estonia on winter warfare exercises with NATO units including soldiers from the Yorkshire Regiment. It is believed members of  Para will be asked to join US airborne troops in demonstrating what the Army calls a Joint Forcible Entry, dramatically dropping into Poland. They are part of  Air Assault Brigade - the UK’s high readiness troops mostly made up of Paratroopers, with signallers, medics and engineers attached.  After jointly parachuting into Poland they would then launch a -day wargaming exercise - as a huge two-finger gesture to the Kremlin, whose troops are currently exercising in Belarus. Sources say the Parachute Regiment is “extremely keen” to perform the drop with the Americans but the MoD and Number Ten are concerned it may be over-aggressive. Senior Parachute Regiment officers have already put forward proposals to PJHQ and the plans are being considered. One source told the Daily Mirror: “The plan is to jump with the nd Airborne who have already arrived, but there is concern and confusion at senior level that any drop will be seen as aggressive and we are waiting for a decision.” The Paras are listed as the UK’s Global Response Force, are already part of an operational readiness capability which was formed with US forces in . More than  British Paras dropped into Ukraine in September , in a joint exercise with local forces and witnessed by the Daily Mirror. They parachuted last year into Jordan with local forces, practising how to battle ISIS and al-Qaeda in counter-terror strikes - an exercise watched by fascinated Russian embassy defence staff.  America has sent , airborne troops into Poland because of the escalating Ukraine crisis and the UK is sending more troops into Estonia.Around  other UK troops are training Ukraineaposs forces in how to fire NLAW anti-tank weapons which have been provided by the UK - with another  preparing for an evacuation.And scores of Special Forces Support Group and SAS troops are in Ukraine secretly preparing to help stranded Brits evacuate by land and airwar breaks out.A Ministry of Defence spokesperson said: “There are currently no plans for  Air Assault Brigade to conduct a jump into Eastern Europe.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON British ArmyEastern EuropeAl-QaedaNatoMinistry of DefenceVladimir PutinSoldiersArmed forcesSpecial forcesFitnessUkraine crisis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Inside incredible mansion with James Bond-style secret tunnels on sale for £ millionOne of the propertys biggest attractions is a mesmerising m tunnel which took miners six months to excavate and even has some secret feature within it.The tunnel Image: Jam Press Vid Jacqui Rowland-Smith of DiJones MosmanByLaura AbernethyGraeme Murray:,  Feb A peek behind the doors of £million mansion has been given and it has its own James Bond-style secret tunnels. The luxurious property, in an upmarket suburb boasts five bedrooms, four bathrooms and world class views views of of one of Australiaaposs most famous landmarks. One of the propertyaposs biggest attractions is a aposmesmerisingapos m tunnel which took miners six months to excavate and even has some secret feature within it. Robert and Wendy Procter, brought underground workers from an opal mine in New South Wales to build the tunnel and during the build on the property in Mosman, Sydney.  The underground feature has attracted the attention of potential buyers after it hit the market with a  millionguide price. It has views over Sydney Opera House and the stone-walled tunnel even houses one of the cityaposs most coveted home gyms complete with a glass wall and wood flooring.Mr Procter told realestate.au : Itaposs a big house and the five of them stayed downstairs … the only thing we didnapost supply was alcohol which would have cost more than the tunnel. Described as very James Bond and high-tech by agent Jacqui Rowland of Di Jones Mosman, the stone tunnel stretches almost theof the entire plot and even has a gym in it. But it is the secret spy tunnel tunnel which has left potential buyers in awe of the property.It’s very James Bond and high-tech,” she told realestate.au. “You come out of the garage and walk into the tunnel, the lights come on and there’s music. It’s mesmerising.” The owners have been in the house for more than four decades but decided to build the underground channel to avoid walking  steps from the street to their house. Mr and Mrs Procter spent all of their million budget to create the game-changing tunnel leading from the double garage to a lt which comes to their home.  It means we donapost have to walk up  steps, which is particularly dficult in the pouring rain, Mr Procter said. Now the tunnel which can be accessed through the double garage goes past a subterannean workout area arriving at a the lt which brings users to their luxury home. In total, the project cost them around  million AUDbut the current owners love the addition.  As well as the wow which the tunnel brings viewers can also imagine themselves on its glorious sun balcony or visiting one of its many rooms or bathrooms.And thereaposs plenty of opportunity to enjoy the glorious weather, as the huge kitchen leads to a garden with a barbecue and entertainment area - as well as a heated pool and spa, sundeck and pond water feature.The estate agents realestate.au. say special equipment was used to bore through the stone.It says: The miners used jackhammers for the vertical lt shaft and a special machine that cut through the rock for the tunnel. He said including the lt and landscaping, there wasn’t much change from m for the work, which he says was well worth it. The views over the city are especially good at night when Sydney Opera House is lit up and can be seen from a distance.The outdoor space allows for some solace and is an oasis of calm in the midst of the bustle of the city.But the couple say the tunnel brings the added value and will see them make a tidy profit from their investment many years ago.  They put the grand mansion on the market for an eye-watering £million but only paid £, when they bought it more than  years ago. The property is on the market with DiJones, with expressions of interest closing on  February. title: kidnapper invented sick lie convince
story: Kidnapper invented sick lie to convince girl Cleo Smith, , to leave her familys tentCleo Smith’s mum has opened up on how her four-year-old daughter was lured away from the family tent at the Blowholes campsite in Western Australia on October  last yearEllie Smith has told how Cleo was lured away from their tent Image:  News  MinutesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCleo Smith’s mum has told that a kidnapper invented a sick story to convince her four-year-old daughter to leave the family tent, saying that her baby sister was unwell.The disappearance of the toddler from a campsite in Western Australia caught the imagination of the world as a desperate search began on October , before she was found  days later.Finally she was traced to the home of Terrence Darrell Kelly,  who has pleaded guilty to taking her from the Blowholes campsite. Several months have now passed since Cleo was reunited with her family but her mum Ellie Smith fears that she will never get over what happened.She said that the four-year-old would wake up shouting and screaming in the night initially.  And now she is scared of being behind locked doors while she insists on sleeping with the lights on. Ellie said how Cleo remembers how she was lured away. “She tells us that she was taken because her baby sister was sick,” she told  Minutes. “And so she needed to be taken away from us to that we could help her baby sister. She just knows a reason as to what he’s told her.”  Cleo’s mum told of the joy when she finally heard the news that she was safe, after receiving a call at am from police. She said: “I was asleep when the phone call came through and I was like ‘this is either good or bad’. I’ve answered it and straight away‘I’ve got someone who wants to say hello to you’ and I was swearing, I was like ‘oh my God, no way’. “Cleo got on to the phone and she’s like ‘hi mummy’ and I was like ‘hi baby’.”Back home Cleo quickly got back to playing with her baby sister Isla but Ellie feels that her child has been changed by what happened. She said how she is “dferent and always will be and that’s just our le now.” The toddler is blocking out what took place with her emotions up and down and Ellie feels that she went into “survivor mode”. Kelly, , was arrested on the same day Cleo was found and he pleaded guilty to forcibly taking a child aged under  at Carnarvon Magistrates Court. Appearing via video link from the high-security prison Casuarina Prison in Perth, he admitted his guilt and was referred to the WA District Court for a sentence mention in March. title: worlds loneliest dog who hasnt
story: Worlds loneliest dog who hasnt left rescue centre in  years needs a forever familyPluto was saved from a Romanian kill shelter at just four days old and ‘will end his le in the centreno one steps in’Worlds most unwanted dog has spent more than a decade in Romanian rescue centre Image: Nobody DogsByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb |commentsThe world’s most unwanted dog has spent  years in a Romanian rescue centre and is still searching for a place to call home. “Sweet” boy Pluto was saved from a kill shelter at just four days old, after his mum and siblings were adopted. Pluto is Nobody Dog’s longest resident and the friendly doggo has never stepped foot outside of the rescue centre’s ranch. And now, the manager of the centre says he will die there is nobody steps in to help. Pluto loves to be around other dogs, cats and children, and would thrive with an active family in a rural area. Alena Stan runs Nobody Rescue in Romania and works with the UK organisation, Bridging The Gap Rescue, to unite stray dogs from kill shelters with families across Europe.“He will end his le in the centreno one steps in and shows him the world,” Alena said. “I’ve had Pluto since he was four days old. “He was born in a public kill shelter with his mum and four siblings in December . “His mum and three siblings were adopted, and Pluto and his brother Dino were left behind. Sadly, Dino recently passed away - so Pluto is the last one left.Pluto is Alena’s longest resident at Nobody Dogs rescue centre and the sweetest boy. “The kennels and shelter is all he’s ever known,” she explained. “He has never left the ranch in the woods.” Alena describes Pluto’s personality as “very friendly and active”. “You wouldn’t know he is a senior dog,” she said. Pluto has never shown any signs of aggression, and gets on well with other dogs, cats and children. He walks well on a lead and would love to live with a family and kids in a rural space.  He has never heard any city sounds before or seen a television, so would need time and patience to adapt. Pluto has spent  years trying to find a place to call home, which has been a struggle for Alena. “We are a very small organisation and it’s dficult to adopt dogs in Romania. People don’t look at private centres,” she explained. While Pluto has lived a long and happy le so far at the rescue, it would be amazing for him to experience the rest of the world and find a permanent family. If you think you could be the perfect home for Pluto, please get in touch withNobody Dogs on Facebook. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. NowHelensburghMore than  houses will be built on the site of Helensburgh Golf Cluban application submitted to Argyll and Bute Council is approved.Taylor Wimpey officially applied for planning permission at the site on East Abercromby Street in the latter part of , and the application has now been validated by Argyll and Bute Council and published on the authority’s website.As well as  residential units the plans also include demolition of the golf club’s existing clubhouse, the building of a new clubhouse and the provision of an enhanced -hole golf course.Feedback can now be given to the authority, with a decision expected from planning officers by Thursday May .A design and access statement by Taylor Wimpey states: #There is a recognised need for new housing within the settlement of Helensburgh.#During the preparation of the Local Development Plan, the council approached the golf club to discuss the possibility of relocating the golf course to provide additional housing land in a sustainable location.#The golf club saw this as an opportunity to improve the existing golf course offer in the area whilst providing land for much-needed housing.#This ultimately led to an area of the golf course being allocated for housing in the adopted Argyll and Bute Local Development Plan.#Members of Helensburgh Community Council have already raised concerns about the impact of increased traffic on East Abercromby Street leading to and from the development’s single access point.In response Taylor Wimpey have said: #Access to the site is currently obtained from East Abercromby Street and the site is bisected roughly north-south by the Old Luss Road footpath and cycleway.#The proposed development will be accessed from a new priority junction on East Abercromby Street, opposite Lever Road and in the general location of an existing access track to Helensburgh Golf Course.#The plans can be viewed on the council’s website at argyll-bute.gov.uk under the reference number   PPMinardMinard Community Trust is putting together a bid for money to refurbish a popular walking track near the village. The proposal would involve replacing the bridge over Auchgoyle Burn on the circular walk around Minard . The works will also include improvements to the surface of approximately  metres of the path either side of the bridge.Before the bid can be submitted to the A’Chruach Wind Farm Community Fund details of the costs involved must be drawn up and to do this the trust is looking for potential contractors to bid for the work.The windfarm fund is provided by Ventient Energy, the developer and owner of the A’Chruach Wind Farm in Argyll and Bute.It aims to support positive change by investing in a wide range of community-led activities that will help create a legacy of lasting impact by making grants to support the costs of relevant projects, services and facilities.The next deadline for funding applications is Friday February .IslayAn unseasonal warning of algae danger has been issued by Argyll and Bute Council regarding Ardnahoe Loch, northeast of Port Askaig.On Tuesday January  an announcement from the council warned residents and visitors not to visit the loch with animals or children.A spokesperson for the council said: #We have been advised of a blue-green algae bloom around the jetty area on Ardnahoe Loch, Islay.Whilst blooms are more usual in the summer months they can still occur at other times of the year. Please keep children and pets away from the area.#KilcregganPlans have been unveiled for five new houses and stables to be built in Kilcreggan.Helensburgh-based KW Contracts have submitted the plans to Argyll and Bute Council for the site at the junction of the B and Portkil Road.The land is currently used for rough grazing, and planning permission has twice been granted for houses at the site before the more recent in .A decision is expected from the council’s planning officers by early March, and the public can now submit comments on the proposal.In a design statement planning agent Gordon Harrison said: #The design solution will be modern rural style of three detached houses and two semi-detached houses. Materials will be traditional render, stone and timber and used in a way to minimise visual impact.#Isle of GighaNature lovers have been asked to get involved in looking after the unique landscape of Gigha through volunteering with the ranger service.One morning each month volunteers carry out conservation tasks to promote and protect the island#s natural heritage.Activities include ditch maintenance, tree planting, bird-box making, rhododendron removal, plantation maintenance and beach cleans.The sessions take place on the third Friday of each month, include tea and coffee and can be signed up for on the gigha.org.uk website.The Isle of Gigha Ranger Service is currently working on habitat management in the woodland that is home to the new path on Achamore Farm.This management aims to increase the iation of the woodland#s structure by encouraging a mosaic habitat that will support everything from insects and butterfly species to bird le.Spaces in the woodland are being cleared of invasive and abundant vegetationto make way for more light-supporting, more erse ground flora and to expose areas where new planting can take place to establish native species that will also support wildle.Woodland edges are also being maintained and encouraged for birds to access resources in neighbouring fields, as well as feed and shelter in the scrub, supporting both woodland and farmland birds.

title: lochgilphead composer creates new islay symphony
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe Royal Scottish National Orchestra has recorded a new symphony written by a Lochgilphead composer who was inspired by the beauty of Islay.The Rinns of Islay, composed by Helen MacKinnon, is a -minute symphony that portrays #a musical journey around the Inner Hebridean island#, which was home to the composer’s grandparents and generations before.Inspired by stories of Islay in her youth, Helen began sketching the work during her composition studies at The University of Glasgow and ed to complete the work nearly  years later.The -minute piece for symphony orchestra was recorded in Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, with American-based PARMA Recordings and GRAMMY-winning producer Brad Michel.Helen, who grew up in Lochgilphead. explained: #It was a privilege to record with Scotland’s national orchestra.#The musicians and conductor, David Watkin, breathed glorious le into the work, which takes us on a musical journey around the island.#Due to Covid, we had a cross-Atlantic recording team, with technology connecting a producer in Boston with a team on the ground in Glasgow. It was a fascinating experience.#The new orchestral work was inspired by Islay’s stunning natural environment, known for its rich terrain and peaty whisky.Five short thematic movements celebrate Islay’s sunrises and coastal shores, while giving a playful nod to the island’s abundant whisky industry.Helen added: #The work centres around The Rinns – a beautul peninsula overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.#My father used to talk about The Rinns of Islay, and as a child, I started to create stories and soundscapes linked to the island.#The work offers a visual, almost cinematic listening experience, with atmospheres and landmarks inspiring the visual imagination.#The work features on a new album Legends and Light Vol. , featuring works by seven composers.While many of the pieces are arranged for orchestral ensembles, listeners will also find the Highland bagpipes and Irish Uilleann pipes featured on the album, offering a deeply rewarding listening experience.Helen is delighted with feedback so far: #I’m thrilled with audiences’ responses to the music.#Listeners have tuned in from across the UK, the USA and as far afield as New Zealand, keeping Scotland on the international map for new music.#

title: debut-goal-new-gala-fairydean-rovers-signing
story: MARTIN Scott believes that Gala Fairydean Rovers’ attacking philosophy will suit new signing Scott Cusick’s style and he will be a good addition to the squad.The Glaswegian came off the bench to score the winner against Dalbeattie Star on Saturday but had to be replaced late on after ‘working his socks off.’Scott said: “We just brought Scotty in recently who was available as a free agent. I had actually played with Scotty when he was on loan at Brechin City from Dunfermline, so I knew what he was capable of. I knew he would fit into our philosophy and how we want to play the game.“My intention was to give him - minutes, but he came on early and worked his socks off and got his reward with the goal and then we had to being him back off because his legs had just went at that point.“He probably needs a bit more game time in terms of match fitness and sharpness but when he gets up to full speed, he will be a real asset for us.“We went short-term and this gives him a chance to get back playing and enjoying his football. And it gives us the opportunity to let him see what we are about and come the end of the season we will probably assess that again.“Everyone knows Gala is a great club. I think that little bit of professionalism and trying to do things in the right manner will help bring him on. He came down and trained with us and as soon as he met the chairman and the boys make everyone feel welcome when they come to the club .“There is a real togetherness there so I think it will suit Scotty going forward so it’s up to him what he does from here until the end of the season. I told him that he will get an opportunity to play but he needs to show me that he’s here to contribute.“He has a good pedigree at Dunfermline and Celtic as a kid and he’s got a good attitude but has just lost his way a bit in terms of going on loan to Brechin City when they were in League Two. It was a tough ask to come in and play men’s football when they were just desperate for results. So it probably wasn’t the ideal fit for him. Going forward, coming to us will suit him as he has an eye for a pass and an eye for a goal and is comfortable on both feet. He can go outside or inside and has a bit of pace. He’ll be a really good addition. “

title: scotland-20s-six-nations-opener-live-bbc-iplayer
story: This will be a proud weekend for the Borders town of Hawick with Stuart Hogg captaining Scotland against the Auld Enemy England tomorrow in the Calcutta Cup match at BT Murrayfield and Rhys Tait doing likewise for the Us tonight at the DAM Health Stadium.Boroughmuir Bear Tait leads Scotland out for the first time from openside flanker as the age-grade sideto play in Scotland for the first time since February .Born and raised in Hawick, Tait started his rugby career at Jed-Forest Minis aged  years old and has already represented Scotland at U and U age-grade level.Tait will be joined in the back row by Matt Deehanwho will make his first appearance in the squad at blindside flanker and Exeter University’s Ollie Leatherbarrow at No  who featured in all five of Scotland’s games last year.Edinburgh Rugby’s Patrick Harrison who enjoyed a successful spell with the Southern Knights last year will start at hooker and will pack down alongside Tom Bantavalaand Currie Chieftains Gregor Scougall who s from injury to take his place in the squad and is set to make his first Scotland U appearance.The imposing figure of Max Williamsonwillto the squad in the second-row and will be joined by Josh Taylor from Ealing Trailfinders.Behind the scrum Jed Gelderbloomstarts at scrum-half and will partner Ayrshire Bulls, and Glasgow Warriors, Christian Townsend at stand-off.It’s an all Boroughmuir Bears mid-field as Mike Gray starts at inside-centre and Duncan Munn at outside him. Ross McKnightand Ollie Melvilleline up on the wings, with Montpellier’s Robin McClintock starting at full-back.Coach Kenny Murray said: “The team are in a really good place after working hard over the last few months.“I’m really happy with the squad we’ve been able to select,  players have played in an international match of this level before, so they know what to expect..remove“It will be a really special night at the DAM Health Stadium on Friday as this group of players get to experience representing their country for the first time on home soil since all  Under- Six Nations fixtures were held in Cardf.“A large crowd is expected so it should be a great atmosphere to open our campaign with.”Scotland U’s opening round of the Under- Six Nations at DAM Health Stadium kicks off at pm and can be watched live on BBC iPlayer.

title: galashiels-road-works-frustrations-voiced-meeting
story: GALASHIELS is “riddled with poorly-maintained road works”, according to a councillor for the town.At a council meeting last week, independent representative Harry Scott raised concerns over “shoddy” repairs carried out on Abbotsford Road near to the fire station.And he asked Gordon Edgar, the executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, when a “full and proper” reinstatement of the road surface will take place.Mr Edgar, a Selkirkshire councillor, said: “This has been causing considerable angst among officers and temporary repairs were undertaken by the contractor back in September, and it had been expected that the permanent reinstatement would have taken place long before now.”He said that Scottish Borders Councilofficers had spoken with the contractors at the start of the year and last week.“They have assured officers that they have made arrangements for this work to be undertaken and hope to confirm the date in the next few days.”Responding, Mr Scott said: “This has been a really frustrating case. Gala is riddled with poorly maintained road works and I’m glad the officers are going to take this up.“Can I ask that they keep the momentum up and that this is not forgotten  This has gone on for two years and it’s time it is resolved.”

title: melrosian-douglas-cant-wait-get-started
story: NEWLY named Melrosian Douglas Crawford “can’t wait” to start in the prestigious role after two years of frustration.He was initially chosen in  but COVID meant that the Melrose Festival along with other Common Ridings and events in the Borders was cancelled.Last year he was able to carry out limited duties such as laying the wreath at the war memorial and taking part in a reduced riding of the boundaries.He told the Border : “Fingers crossed that it goes ahead as normal. It was announced at Melrose Rugby Club by Rob Moffat who is the Festival Director on Saturday. Obviously, I’ve known for some time, but it means so much to me and my family and I am very proud. It’s a great honour and I can’t wait to get started.“Will Owen who also plays for Melrose was named ‘Melrosian elect’ so he can use this summer to see how it’s done which is a change. He will be my left hand man and Ben McGowan who was the last Melrosian in  will be my right-hand man. Having Robas Chairman will be a help as he is a ‘go to’ man who can keep me rightneeded.”Douglas follows in the footsteps of his father Mike who was Melrosian in , Uncle Cameron in  and brother Donald who led the town’s  celebrations.So has he had advice from the family  “Keep hold of the horse for dear le,” he joked. “And I should throw myself into it and enjoy all the festivals in the Borders. It will be an amazing experience and I intend to follow that advice as much as I can although I will need to get back on the horse as I haven’t ridden since last year when Ben, Harry Fletcher and I did an unofficial ride around the boundaries.”After attending St Mary’s School in Melrose, Douglas studied at Merchiston Castle School in Edinburgh before completing an undergraduate degree in psychology at Bath University and working as a recruitment consultant in London for a year. He is currently studying for a doctorate at Glasgow University in Sports Psychology..removeThis year’s Queen and her court have still to be named.If everything goes to plan, the Melrose Festival will take place from Sunday th June - Saturday th June.

title: new-biking-festival-set-arrive-peeblesshire
story: HUNDREDS of people will finally arrive in Peeblesshire for a new biking festival this year – two years later than planned.The enduro-style event will take place between April -May  in the grounds of landmark Traquair House.Muck n’ Mac Festival, the brainchild of Cameron Balfour, was initially planned for July  but suffered two years of setbacks due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, the -year-old says he is “excited” for his work to finally come to fruition.“We started doing the work on it in  and we were initially meant to be having it in July , but obviously with COVID we had to reschedule it,” said Cameron, who was part of Peebles Cycling Club as a kid. “We rescheduled it to last year and then it fell again when we were in a heavy lockdown.“It’s just been such a long period of work on it, I’m just excited to see it all together in one finished product.“It’s been knocking on three years’ work.”Across the weekend at Traquair House, visitors can expect to find a range of onsite catering including a bar, live music sessions, film screenings, yoga and wellness sessions and family friendly activities.Riding at Muck n’ Mac Festival is open to anyone aged  and over and riders can bring a road bike, gravel mountain bike, or E-bike.And children can enjoy the weekend for free with a paying adult.“For me the point I’m most excited for is the Saturday evening after the first day’s riding,” said Cameron, who grew up in Heriot. “I’m looking forward to that sense of comradery – everyone’s been out on their bikes through the day, they’ve had that challenging day and come the evening time just everyone sitting down over a pint talking about their stories from the day and a bit of live music.”Cameron has always had a passion for biking, riding the trails around Innerleithen as a youngster.“I come from a cycling background myself,” he said, “I love cycling, it’s my passion. As a kid I was part of the Peebles Cycling Club..remove“[In] Peebles and Innerleithen is really where my cycling began. I grew up learning to ride mountain bikes and exploring.“It’s a fantastic area for riding bikes, it’s the trail I know best and I think it’s a great area for folks to be riding bikes.”Now, the -year-old is hoping that the first Muck n’ Mac Festival will not only be a fun event for the adult riders taking part, but will also encourage young people to get outside more.“The big driver is the cycling aspect,” he said. “To get more folk out riding bikes and to look at cycling from a dferent perspective.“I think there’s a lot of people, like myself for example, who were very much into the competitive side of it and kind of fell out of love with it.“So we’re trying to look at cycling from a dferent perspective and add extra elements to it, not so much the serious racing approach.“With the event being free for kids and the outdoor activities, just trying to get kids hooked on that outdoor type lestyle and getting more involved in the outdoors.”A full weekend riding ticket is £, a ticket for a single day riding is £, and a festival village pass is £.All tickets include the cost of camping at Traquair.For more information, visit: www.mucknmacfest

title: youth-climate-activists-play-part-town
story: PUPILS at a Peeblesshire school have highlighted the climate crisis with a walk through the community, handing out leaflets.Last week the young climate activists from St Ronan’s Primary School took to the streets in Innerleithen to raise awareness of climate change.And the youngsters also gave leaflets to passersby and displayed handmade signs featuring a range of environmental messages.Dawn Taylor, depute headteacher at St Ronan’s said: “The group are very passionate about sharing their climate message.“They have been involved in organising and planning the event showing great initiative, independence and leadership.“This learning has linked in really well with COP and the children’s passion for the environment, but has also supported the development of our school core skills for learning, le and work.“The children are all from our Primary  cohort within the school and have led art lessons and learning activities within their classrooms in order to raise awareness around protecting the environment.“They have also organised and advertised the local awareness walk around the community.“The walk today is taking place both around the school and the local community and is a way for them to share their important message.“We are very proud of them here at St Ronan’s Primary School.”

title: townsend-not-getting-carried-away-england-win
story: A delighted Gregor Townsend hailed his Scotland players after they retained the Calcutta Cup with a - victory over England at BT Murrayfield yesterday.London Irish scrum-half Ben White opened the scoring after good work by Hawick man Darcy Graham then a penalty try followed after England hooker Luke Cowan was sinbinned following a deliberate knock-on.  Finn Russell also converted two penalties and a conversion of the White try.It was the first time since  that Scotland had won back-to-back games in the fixture and the fans celebrated long into the Edinburgh night.The Borders’ man isn’t getting carried away with thoughts of a first Six Nations title though and remembers last year when they failed to build on the victory over England at Twickenham by losing to Wales at Murrayfield.He said: “Last year we started really well, and that showed the confidence the players had from their win at Twickenham. We were - upso how we prepared last year was fine.“It was just how we dealt with situations like not scoring a try in the Wales  at the end of the first half and giving away three penalties in a row to hand momentum back to Wales, then in the second half, not dealing with the red card when we needed to adjust.“Confidence and belief is important, it gives you the ability to adapt and show character, but we have to deliver the detail as well. We can be better than this week, and we believe Wales will be better than they showed this week.“Being tough to beat is really important. It usually defines championship-winning teams, a strong defence in any sport. We know our defence is really entwined with our attack. We’ve got some really dangerous attackers in our team who we want to give the ball to.“Getting both of those sides of the game right is so important. But defence certainly helps you win those tight games.”

title: royal-mint-reveals-10-rarest-50p-coins-circulation
story: The Royal Minthas revealed its top ten rarest  pence coins in circulation.The move to ‘new money’ pounds and pence, happened  years ago this month, with the anniversary on  February .Since then, over  iations of the p coin have been circulating and several rare designs have been distributed.The famous Kew Gardens p remains the most coveted coin in circulation, with a mintage of just ,, the Mint said.Other rare designs include Olympic-themed ps minted in .Here, we look at the rarest p coins and how many of each have been made - and how much they could be worth.What makes a coin valuable The  pence piece has become the most valued and collected coin in the UK, with many collectable designs appearing on its heptagonal canvas.Its .mm diameter makes it the largest of any British coin, and allows space for decorative pictures. It has often been used to celebrate big events over the past  years of British history.The rarest coins tend to be of the greatest value, with the mintagebeing the fundamental attraction for collectors.Along with the design, other aspects of the coin which increase value are the condition of the coin and whether it has an error in its design.The way in which it is sold can also determine the coin’s value - while some coin collectors will bid vast amounts of money on ebay or at auction, others opt for more robust valuations by selling via a coin dealer.Rarest p coins in circulation the UK The Royal Minthas revealed the most valuable p coin, ahead of the  decimalisation’s golden anniversary.The rarest is the Kew’s Garden p, which was designed to mark the th anniversary of the gardens in . Only , coins were ever minted with this design.The Kew Gardens p sells for £. on average, but one seller received over £ for one when they sold it on ebay.The other rarest coins stem predominantly from the  Olympics, with the wrestling, football and judo coins among the most valuable. Only .million of each of these coins were produced..removeFlopsy bunny and Peter Rabbit designs which were produced in  are also highly valuable.These coins - . million of which were minted - depict the characters from Beatrix Potter’s novels and celebrate the le of the English writer and these sell for around £.In ,  million coins were produced, with three new p designs.These included one of Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes, Paddington Bear at St Pauls Cathedral and the Tower of London.Top  most valuable p coins, according to Royal MintHere is a list of the top  most valuable coins, when they were made and how many were minted:Kew Gardens , ,Olympic Wrestling , ,,Olympic Football , ,,Olympic Judo , ,,Olympic Triathlon , ,,Peter Rabbit , ,,Flopsy Bunny , ,,Olympic Tennis , ,,Olympic Goalball , ,,Olympic Shooting , ,,

title: travellers-reviews-list-borders-town-uk-top-10-list
story: THE Scottish Borders town of Kelso has been recognised as one of the most welcoming places in the UK according to a new analysis of traveller reviews.The Top  Most Welcoming Towns in the UK list was based on booking’s user reviews of their experiences with hospitality.The report was compiled by looking at reviews for more than , travel providers in the UK and was based on the proportion of properties receiving one of its Traveller Review Awards in .The top  destinations were sorted by the total share of recipients when compared to the total amount of eligible properties in that city or region.Destinations had to have at least  award recipients in each city to be included in this list and were sorted by the highest share of winners per destination.Other Scottish towns in the top- were Kirkwall, Lerwick and Wick.Booking’s full list of the most welcoming towns and cities in the UK was:. Enniskillen . Kirkwall, Orkney . Ballycastle . Lerwick, Shetland Islands . Wick, Highlands . Bushmills . Douglas, Isle of Man . Frome, Somerset  . Newcastle, Co Down   Glastonbury, Somerset   Kelso, Scottish BordersRyan Pearson, Regional Manager for Booking, commented: “Looking ahead to the future with renewed optimism and hope, with these awards we want to recognise the incredible hospitality our partners deliver to travellers each and every day and thank them for their amazing efforts as we continue to rebuild together.”

title: council-looks-write-off-beaune-properties-100k-debt
story: A FORMER Borders property company’s debt totalling around £, will be written off,councillors approve plans this week.The local authority’s executive committee are due to meet virtually at am on Tuesdayto discuss the matter.In  an invoice was raised for around £, with Beaune Properties for boarding to secure the site at Harriers Hut, Bath Street, Hawick, according to Scottish Borders Councilpapers.A further  invoices were raised on an account in the name of Beaune Properties Ltd from October  to May  totalling close to £,.:Borders woman bit one police officer and slapped another during disturbanceThese charges were to stabilise a dangerous building and enforcement works at Hawick’s Wilton Mill on Commercial Road, the SBC report states.Court proceedings were raised against Beaune Properties in  , with both parties asked to go to mediation to avoid a full evidentiary hearing.The papers state: “Mediation took place in  where a qualied mediator oversaw the meeting. The meeting was attended by senior officers from SBC and representatives from Beaune Properties.“The outcome agreed was for Beaune Properties to pay SBC the sum of £, in full and final settlement of all sums due with the agreement drawn up in the names of Beaune Properties Ltd and Beaune Properties North Limited.“This agreement was transferred at a later date to Beaune Properties North Ltd alone and Beaune Properties Ltd was dissolved in September .”:-year-old Borders man who died in two-car crash on Melrose bypass is namedHowever, despite making the agreement the company failed to pay the £,, with the council’s requests for the payments met with responses asking for further time.Beaune Properties North Ltd then wanted to enter into further discussion on the agreed amount, according to the report.The company was then dissolved in August ..removeSBC is now looking to write off the “irrecoverable” debt, with approval of elected members needed for any sum greater than £,.

story: Are there areas in the Scottish Borders where you feel unsafe Police officers want to know and  they have launched an -minute survey where participants can place virtual pins on a map to identy dangerous locations.A maximum of three pins can be placed on the map and those taking part will be asked to provide much detail as possible.Locations may be street names, buildings, areas of towns cities, or names of parks and it is important to be specic.Participants are then asked what specically makes them feel less safe in this area and what would make this area feel more safe for them This new service lets the public anonymously tell officers about public places where they have felt or feel unsafe, because of environmental issues, e.g. street lighting, abandoned buildings or vandalism and or because of some behaviours, e.g. being followed or verbally abused.Other questions asked include how safe do you feel in your local area To what extent has your concern about crime in your local area increased or decreased in the last  months What are the police doing well in your local area And is there anything the police could do better to support communities in your local area The survey can be accessed at Police Scotland’s Facebook page.
